reviewText:
I didn't enjoy this game when it came out. I tried out, and I didn't understand the battle mechanism, didn't understand the character switching, it was just so different from the LEGO® Star Wars™ - The Complete Saga.

When this was on discount, I read all the reviews, I watched some gameplay footage, and I remembered how much I loved the Star Wars - Clone Wars series. And hell yes. This game is all about the series, the maps are the key episodes.
And in my eyes the Clone Wars is not a cartoon, it is much more Star Wars than the sequel trilogy:
when Ben Kenobi is talking to Luke about the great war, this is it! Yeah, Episode III also shows 1-2 battles, but this game IS the great war.

The maps are following the events of the series, amd after learning the unique technique of the game, you will enjoy it as much as any other LEGO games. Win battle in the space, siege the enemy base in the ground, and finish the map as following the original Clone Wars story. 10/10 would buy again.
Another LEGO game where I achieved 100%. Can't wait the LEGO Force Awakens.

reviewText:
Lego Star Wars III - The Clone Wars follows the TV series: Star Wars - The Clone Wars. How well it does, I don't know, as I haven't regularly watched the show. It did, however, let me play through the very few parts of the show I remembered, so I'll have to leave how well it followed the show to the assumption that it does a decent job.

As for the level design, there are plenty of good levels in this game, but are sadly overshadowed by the abundance of strategic open battlefield levels. You have to destroy enemy bases and build your own. It's fun and makes for a great side activity to be included (as it did in the game's Republic Assault missions) but it's also put in place of some of the actual story missions which just seems a bit lazy to me.

The controls feel like the other Lego Star Wars games (I used a gamepad controller) but with what I would consider a major improvement. They removed the short combos from the previous games and replaced it with the ability to fight indefinitely. One thing I do miss, however, is the ability to use stronger lightsaber attacks by timing your next move instead of button mashing.

Overall, I love this game but wouldn't give it a perfect score.

reviewText:
This game is a Lego game as we know them but its also a bit of a strategy game!

They tried something different and implemented a sort-of-strategy mode where you build production buildings and take out the enemies base step by step. Its really great, as are the 'story' and the normal gameplay. Its just a very well made Lego game with a bit of a twist.

Also it comes with a really big 'hub-world' aka. two spaceships, one clone-ship and one of the seperatists with tons of stuff to explore and riddles to be solved.

I'd give it a 9/10 because it doesn't just do the story and is done with it like other Lego games did. Honestly this is a great game and you don't have to like the cartoon series to like this game.

reviewText:
This game has a severe case of console-portitis. And the only cure is a controller.

This game is good, but was ported from console to PC poorly, and although it runs smoothly, the controls suck. But if you use a controller, then the controls are just fine. Any controller will do really, but the prompts will be Xbox controller buttons. But that is not a huge issue. I use a PS3 controller using the Scarlet.Crush drivers. You could also use Motioninjoy, but the Scarlet.Crush drivers are better.

So far, the levels have been good, they were not repeats of the same thing or anything like that.

And I love the new RTS style levels.

reviewText:
,It's a fun game. If you like the LEGO games already, you'll enjoy this a lot. Way more fun that LEGO Star Wars The Complete Saga, mostly due to an increase in variety, particularly in terms of the Jedi character's fighting styles and abilities. Only draw back is it's short, three storylines of six levels with four additional ones as opposed to the 6 sets of 6 in TCS. 30-40 hours to reach 100% completion and after that point you'll likely lose interest. Probably best to buy when on sale.

Also fun to play local co-op if you have a friend or sibling to do so with.

If you don't own a controller, don't buy. Very hard to play with just the keyboard.

reviewText:
No Momento em que você quiser participar do Universo graças ao Episódio VII, Pense
Compare nesse momento que se estenderá até 2020, de intenso Hype por tudo o que se relacionar a Star Wars, qual a diferença entre Battlefront e Lego Star Wars, falo aqui pelo Clone Wars e também pelo Complete Saga completado nos aureos tempos de PS2.

Obviamente, um é FPS mal explicado e infimo por 120 reais, o outro é voltado a retratar a história das duas trilogias de forma bem humorada e divertida, pra qualquer idade, com muito mais detalhes, por apenas 11 reais.

Há a necessidade de mais explicação?

Não há, na minha opinião, melhor jogo de Star Wars a não ser os Battlefronts originais, não há!

Mais e os gráficos?
Sensácionais, dentro dos limites de um jogo Lego, é claro, mas caso você tenha jogado apenas as versões de PS2, vai achar que é um jogo de 2015!

reviewText:
Personally, even I don't know why I'm giving this game a negative review. Maybe I'm just spoiled on what Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga already delivered...

Naaaaaah!

Lego Star Wars III- The Clone Wars is the next game Traveler's Tales was contractually obligated to make from Star Wars, before they'd lose the rights, which I'm sure they're refreshing with their new release for The Force Awakens. And, as always, there's a problem with the Traveler's Tales Lego games that seems to have started with this entry...

Traveler's Tales doesn't believe in patience. At all.

Why wait for us to do a complete Indiana Jones, when we could release two? I know! Let's also release Lego The Hobbit within months of Battle of the Five Armies, but not include it in out game! Wait! I've got another idea! How about we make Lego Star Wars: The Force Awakens, before the other two entries are even made!

It's sad, honestly. I really like certain elements of LSW III that I do like. The new characters and locations inspired from the Clone Wars film and TV series are all fun to play as, beautifully animated, and great to control. There's tons of new abilities available, allowing tons of new opportunities for puzzles, such as mnigun targets, grappling, and precise Force movements.

However, this feels like a really shoddy attempt to give these new abilities so light to shine in. There were a fair share of puzzles in the original LSW games that didn't outright tell you the answer, but you could figure them out with your own deduction skills. But with the way the puzzles are set up for the new abilities, it's always obvious what you have to do next.

On top of that, if Traveler's Tales had waited for the ENTIRE series to finish its run, they would have had a lot more opportunities at their hands. Hundreds of characters, tons of new planets to choose from, and even more abilities you could create.

But it really feels like they chose the most boring planets to visit. Out of all the levels I played, I only liked Ambush, Rookies, Lair of Grievous, Hostage Crisis, and Castle of Doom for their aesthetics. 5 out of about 25 levels. Because most of them are either space levels, running around dark, metal corridors, or battlefiels in the middle of a desert.

Where's the snowy tundras of Trespass"? Where's the swamps of Rodia from "Bombad Jedi"? The massive fungal world from "Bounty Hunters"? It doesn't feel like TT chose the most creative or unique planets from the show to focus on.

Along with that

reviewText:
I don't like this game because it makes me feel like an idiot... I can figure out the freaken tombs in Tomb Raider, yet a game played by children makes me feel like I should hand back my college degree.

You are dropped into a situation and you feel like Yoda is flipping you off because he tells you this character is needed which you don't have, but does he give you a hint on what to actually do? Nope.

The fighting isn't really interesting, I didn't expect it to be but I would like to understand how I am getting hurt. I don't see how I'm getting hit, or really when. A noise to tell me that I got hit would go along way.

The sad thing is, it's probably still better than battlefront.

reviewText: I used to play Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga all the time as a kid and I loved it. When I saw this game, I decided I would give it a try... once it went on sale. May the 4th sales finally came and I bought it. What a disappointment. The battles are not nearly as fun as the Complete Saga because they have replaced the lightsaber block with a lightsaber throw which means you are just mindlessly swinging a lightsaber instead of trying to deflect blasts. The battlefields are huge and monotonous to traverse (not to mention they have terrible camera angles.) The whole system of how you destroy blocks is extremely annoying: Only explosions work on silver. Only rapid fire units (which are rare and annoying to use) work on gold, and its not just blocks, but vehicles too. You spend most of you time trying to find a vehicle or weapon that will destroy the one target you need to capture a base. The whole squad system" and the fact that you must coordinate multiple units to destroy one object is unnecessarily cumbersome in a game that should have simple play mechanics. My biggest gripe
recommended: is the fact that this game is WAY less intuitive in level design than its predecessors. I've encountered multiple scenarios in most of the missions (including the very first one) where I am completely lost and have no idea what the game wants me to do. This game is just not rewarding enough for me to even consider free play mode.\n\nOn the plus side
hoursPlayed: there are numerous jokes and visual gags in the cut scenes typical of a LEGO game."
votesTotal: 20 of 51 people (39%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I shouldn't have finished this game because I hated it. My brother who I co-oped the whole thing with hated it as well. We were actually sort of excited to play it too after working through the entirety of The Clone Wars show in November/December. I didn't think Lego games had changed too much over the years, but this game changed my stance on that. There were just so many awkward moments of level design that left my brother and me bewildered as to what the devs actually wanted us to do to progress forward. They also did this half-♥♥♥ RTS level experiment that is simultaneously dumbed down for the age-group of the target demographic and bit too complicated and irritating for that same age group. As an adult it's hard not to wonder what the hell they were thinking when they put those levels together. They also decided to dump them all into one of the level arcs too, leading to some bizarre pacing where we were stuck playing a bunch of them back to back (boy were tempted to co-op the delete button there). The game makes almost no effort to make good use of the source material- they skipped over a lot of episodes that had good potential and opted for some of the weakest ones. I do recommend checking out the show on Netflix though. It is the proper 2:35 presentation and has a lot of story arcs that are the some of the best Star Wars stories out there.\n\nVerdict: Hard pass.

reviewText: I love the Lego games and Lego Star Wars, but this.. just isn't a Lego game.\nI understand that when this came out people were saying how Lego games were getting stale, and so Travellers Tales decided to change up the gameplay, the problem is what they changed it too is a boring sub-RTS with some normal levels sprinkled in. I've only played 3 levels all of which were short and boring, if they had only made this game with similar but updated gameplay from the last 2 games, it would've been perfect. Note, that even if you love the cartoon, it's still not worth it, I recommend just getting the Complete Saga, an older but much better game then this.

reviewText: As a big fan of the LEGO games, it pains me to say that this is a bad game. While the characters feel much more realized compared to their LEGO Star Wars 1 and 2 counterparts, the game inherently fails in the gameplay front. Levels are really poorly designed with puzzles very obviously forced upon the player, as they make no sense in the context of not only the story, but the setting themselves. While I respect the fact that the game experiments with the wierd army/base levels, they eventually become driving into the enemy base with your mediocre vehicle to shoot down the turrets as no one attacks you. This failed experiment unfortunately makes up a third of the game. The hub is also an absolute travesty. Places are hard to reach and it is never clear where anything is. You can't even get a bounty hunter character until you make a spaceship and fly to a different base. I can go on and on about why this game isn't good, but to me it's clear that Traveller's Tales didn't really know what they were doing here.

reviewText:
I'm genuinely confused by all the positive reviews for this game, because off the top of my head I can name several bad things.
1. Unskippable cutscenes. (THAT ARE LONG)
2. Poor controls (I'll go into deeper detail in a minute)
3. Confusing missions.
Being a fan of the original LEGO Star Wars series, I purchased this game in hopes it would be similar to the others, which it seemed to be at first, but naturally with a modern twist. I had no complaints up until I tried the first mission. The controls were completely different from the original game, which makes no sense I might add. They clearly went about this in an attempt to recreate the old game, but they messed with the controls that had existed in the earlier version.

ONE LAST THING: This game is clearly directed torwards children, unlike the old game. You can tell by how shiny and cute" everything is. It's too bad they didn't just recreate the old game with new parts

reviewText:
I don't feel it is a great choice if you are new to the lego game series.
didn't get on with this game. I have no idea what i'm suppose to be doing most of the time. The instructions are non existent, i've tried exploring a bit and still, every part of the game seems to leave me in a room with no instruction as to how to get out. I keep getting hint messages telling me what to do.. but still nothing happens when i try and do it. definitely not a game for those who have never played the lego games before. presume you need to be experienced with them before this is any fun

EDIT:
Perhaps I need to clarify a few things that I said above. I'm not saying that the game itself is bad, I can see it is highly regarded by others as a good game. The puzzle solving concept with a lego, star wars theme is right up my street. The problem I have with this game is that I don't feel it is a great choice if you are new to the lego game series. This is the message I wanted to get across to people. I understand that it is a sequel to existing games, however, I would have liked there to be a simple (perhaps optional) tutorial that gently walks a person through the games concepts so that I could play this game without having played any others in the lego series.

Consider my situation and then my experience with the game.
I am someone who has never played any lego game before, I do not have a spouse or sibling here with me to give me a brief overview of how to play the game.
The first thing I do is click start game. I then watch a 2 minute video that sets the scene and the game begins.
The game expects me to know
(1) what the game controls are (I think a lot of people will tend to have a brief look before they play, like I did, but I expect many will like to figure most of this stuff out as they play).
(2) Knowledge about switching players
(3) What actions each character can do
(4) Know how the use special actions with certain characters (e.g. using the force to push an object)
I feel that this is already quite a lot to have to know about, and then on top of all this, if I don't figure all of this out within a 3 minute time period, the characters get attacked by monsters and I failed that bit of the level.
I then get put back to the start menu and click play game, I have to sit through the same 2 minute video again because there didn't appear to be an obvious way to skip it.
I do this 3 or 4 times, before I google how to escape this first scene. I would say that’s a pretty poor introduction to a game... And the game goes on, without the time pressure element, but still there is little guidance for the kind of things I'm expected to do. I would say that the game hasn't given me the right opportunities to established a thought process that I need, that will allow me to explore the ideas ive already been introduced to, and using what ive learnt to complete new challenges.

Now, I believe that if the game designers target audience were new players who had never played any lego game before, this first sequence would never have passed testing! I think they would have put greater focus on a step-by-step learning process within the opening challenges of the game before the player is thrown in at the deep end. There are no tutorial level and very little in terms of introducing players to the game concepts. I therefore have to assume that the designers of the game were intending this to be a game for more experienced players.

That is all there is to it. I think that if I had known this before purchasing the game, I would definetly have bought a different game from the lego series. One that would allow a beginner to have a good time.

reviewText: As a massive fan of both Star Wars and the LEGO game franchise of course I'm gonna love this. If you've played any of the other LEGO games you pretty much know a lot of the basics you're gonna find here. It's a great time, although I did find it infinitely more frustrating than any of the others. You can play the game in pretty much any order you want. There are three branching chapters" if you will. One centered around Count Dooku
recommended: and one centered around General Grievous. There's no specific order you have to play the levels in

voteText: and I can't figure out quite what that order is. There were levels I would play and feel almost lost. There is very little explanation of what you're supposed to do

votesFunny: requires you to hit them with rapid fire or a consistent laser beam. And I only know that because I looked it up. Not once in five hours has the game told me that
column16: especially since the game is meant for kids. However despite that it is a load of fun

column23: and in one Captain Rex completely disappeared after a while
column24: right when I realized he was the only character I had who I needed anymore. But I imagine at least that last problem is something that will be fixed by restarting the level
column25: so while it's annoying I'm assuming it's not too game-breaking."

reviewText: After the disappointment of LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga I was not expecting to like this game; I thought it would be like the first game except without the familiar story. When I started playing however it was apparent that there have been significant improvements. There was a colourful and varied range of characters that seemed to have more personality to them; the tedious challenge mode and super story modes had gone; there was a nice level hub with plenty of things to unlock; the levels were enjoyable. So all in all it was going well and it didn't matter that I knew nothing about the plot of the clone wars. Then came the ground battle levels. These kind of RTS type levels are quite frankly terrible, the units you build do nothing significant, the two sides just keep ineffectually sending wave after wave of troops at each other. The only reason to build up your base is to get the more powerful vehicles needed to destroy the gold and silver buildings then once you have those you can ignore all your units and go and destroy the enemy base on your own. Then there is the sheer quantity of these levels outside the main story line there are about 15 of these that you have to compete twice, once for each side. It is like they removed the tedious parts of the first game then felt they had to fill the void with something doubly tedious. Once you have the super speeder red brick you can churn your way through these a little more easily. So overall I'm giving it a thumbs up because it is enjoyable and a little better than LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga but it does not measure up to most of the other LEGO games.

reviewText:
The Lego Star Wars Games were the first set of lego games and are what made the games so popular with kids and adults alike. They are funny, family friendly and were able to tell a story simply with the character's grunts an giggles. Does Lego Star Wars 3 live up to the expectation?

The first thing you will notice is that the animations have been significantly overhauled which some may consider a good thing and some won't. The characters don't feel or look like toys anymore which I like. There's enough cartoon like momments that make the game feel like you are playing with one massive Lego set but I would have prefered they had just made the animations more realistic and left the character designs like they were in Lego Star Wars 1 and 2.

The game is quite like an RPG. The hub is no longer a small cantina, it is two massive spaceships (republic and seperatist) and a big chunk of space in between the ships. You can hop in mini lego spaceships (and some classics like Slave 1) and defeat the enemy which will convert the planet you are fighting over to your chosen faction.

The levels are what you would expect from a Lego game, simplistic puzzles that an eight year old could solve, straightforward bossfights and lots, and lots of jumping!

Lego Star Wars 3 is a good game but has taken Lego characters to the point were they look a lot more realistic, the animation overhaul is well done but there really isn't much of a challenge to be had.
7.75/10

reviewText:
In my opinion this game is alot better than Saga, the graphics are better, the mechanics are better and it's just a whole lot funner to play. But for me there is one con, controller support. This game has partial controller support but you need special logitech or whatever remotes to play with it, you can't play with an Xbox or PS3 controller which is quite dissapointing. I don't understand it either because Saga had full controller support and this doesn't even though the controls are almost identical, plus it makes it even worse so you can't use your mouse in this either, I don't believe that this review will make them try to add full controller support since it is so old now but it's worth a try :/

EDIT:
For some reason when I just re-opened the game my wired Xbox One controller was working with the game, I have no idea why this has happened but I'm really happy about it :) maybe it does work with these controllers after all...?.

reviewText: It's really good if you like Lego Star Wars. Presentation and gameplay are redefined in this Lego Star Wars game and it is, dare I say it...., even better than Lego Star Wars: The Complete Saga. Awesome models, hub world, and fun gameplay. Only downside is the tedious grind to get some of the gold bricks in a sort of RTS" clones vs droids sidegame. I bought it for $5.99 and it was worth every penny despite it's downsides! 9.3/10"

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The only reason I bought this game is because I used to have the complete saga on PS3.  Well let me tell you something.  This game ROCKS!!!  I can't believe the amount of characters they somehow fit into every Lego game.  This game goes with the storyline of the Star Wars the clone wars tv show.  I remember each part clearly.  Although there are 1 too many full fledged battles where you have to setup these stations of troops and weapons the addition of anti aliasing in this game makes up for anything bad.

Pros:
Fun
Childhood memories WILL be brought back
AA
decent story length
Not too expensive for what you get
At least 150 characters

Cons:
Station battles
You have to watch the tv show to understand the campaign well.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Players: References to 80's sci-fi movies?

Star Wars Lego III: no problem

Players: Hot twi'lek babes on the side of your gunship?

Star Wars Lego III: no problem

Players: Jacked, shirtless clone troopers?

Star Wars Lego III: no problem

Players: Custom alien character?

Star Wars Lego III: sorry, I support Trump

Players: Violence?

Star Wars Lego III goes silent, turning to look at the window as it silently reflects on the violent horrors brought on by its predecessors. Every blocky death that flashes through its mind brings a wince to it's sold out face. It then turns back to the players to reply.

Star Wars Lego III: I'm not that kind of game anymore
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I've completed this game 3 times on other consoles but i still wanted to play this on my pc. keyboard controls are clunky to me however some people may easily get used to them. The game itself is amazing,  if only it had controler support then i would recomend this game  but wait, it has controller support!. There is co-op, but on a keyboard? Probably not the easiest thing in the world. this game is probable easyer to play on the wii than on a keyboard. However that aside, this game is amazing. This game has some awesome tower defence missions and you can battle your friends with an attack and tower defence gamemode. Have no friends? Well it doesn't matter because you can play that gamemode against te computer in a different type of the same gamemode. And play this on many of the planets that were local in the clone wars! Overall This is an amazing game so go buy it for your friends! Your family! Everyone!
